member.name: M:Couchbase.CouchbaseExtensions.VerifySuccess``1(Couchbase.IDocumentResult{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Throws an exception if a document operation was not successful.
member.param: Indicates whether the operation has replication or persistance constraints.

member.name: M:Couchbase.CouchbaseExtensions.VerifySuccess``1(Couchbase.N1QL.IQueryResult{``0})
member.summary: Throws an exception if a query operation was not successful.
member.exception: Thrown for errors.
Thrown if the error is potentially transient and the operation should be retried.

remarks.para:
This method is similar to the built-in Couchbase
method, but may be better for many situations for these reasons:

list.item:
This method includes information about the specific errors detected.
only returns a generic Fatal Error message and expects you to examine the property in your code. This methods does that for you by including the errors in the exception message so that that they will be included in any diagnostic logging your doing without any additional effort.
This method throws a if the error indicates that it should be retried. This makes it easy to use a Neon to perform retries.

member.name: M:Couchbase.CouchbaseExtensions.CheckAsync(Couchbase.Core.IBucket)
member.summary: Performs small read/query operations to verify that the database connection is healthy.
member.exception: Thrown if the bucket is not ready.

member.name: M:Couchbase.CouchbaseExtensions.WaitUntilReadyAsync(Couchbase.Core.IBucket,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Waits until the bucket is ready.
member.param: Optionally specifies the maximum time to wait (defaults to 60 seconds).
member.exception: Thrown if the operation timed out.

summary.para: Waits for any pending database updates to be indexed. This can be used to implement read your own writes..
summary.note: IMPORTANT: This is intended for use only for databases with a #primary index.

remarks.para: You may explicitly pass =true for development and test environments where there may not be enough cluster nodes to satisfy durability constraints. member.name: T:Couchbase.NeonBucket
member.summary: Wraps an adding some additional capabilities.

remarks.para: This bucket can be configured to ignore replicate and persist durability constraints. You can explicitly pass ignoreDurability=true to the constructor for development and test environments where there may not be enough cluster nodes to satisfy durability constraints. If this is null (the default) then the bucket will look for the presence of the DEV_WORKSTATION environment variable and ignore durability constraints if this variable exists.

This means that production and staging environments that don't have the DEV_WORKSTATION environment variable will enforce durability by default and development/test environments that have this set will not enforce durability be default.

member.name: P:Couchbase.NeonBucket.ReadyTimeout
member.summary: HACk: Returns the timeout used when ensuring that a bucket is ready for use.

member.name: P:Couchbase.NeonBucket.ReadyRetry
member.summary: HACk: Returns the retry policy used when ensuring that a bucket is ready for use.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Optionally configure the bucket to ignore durability parameters.

remarks.para: You may explicitly pass =true for development and test environments where there may not be enough cluster nodes to satisfy durability constraints. If this is null (the default) then the bucket will look for the presence of the DEV_WORKSTATION environment variable and ignore durability constraints if this variable exists, otherwise durability constraints will be honored.

member.name: P:Couchbase.NeonBucket.IgnoreDurability
member.summary: Indicates whether this bucket is ignoring any and/or durability constraints. This is useful for unit testing where it'll be likely that there won't be enough Couchbase cluster nodes to satisfy durability constraints for production code.

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.Servers
member.summary: One or more Couchbase server URIs.
member.remarks: You must specify the URI for at least one operating Couchbase node. The Couchbase client will use this to discover the remaining nodes. It is a best practice to specify multiple nodes in a clustered environment to avoid initial connection problems if any single node is down.

member.summary: Maximum time (milliseconds) to wait to establish a server connection (defaults to 10 seconds).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.SendTimeout
member.summary: Maximum time (milliseconds) to wait to transmit a server request (defaults to 10 seconds).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.OperationTimeout
member.summary: Maximum time (milliseconds) to wait for an operation to complete (defaults to 10 seconds).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.QueryRequestTimeout
member.summary: Maximum time (milliseconds) to wait for a non-view query to complete (defaults to 75 seconds).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.ViewRequestTimeout
member.summary: Maximum time (milliseconds) to wait for a view query to complete (defaults to 75 seconds).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.MaxPoolConnections
member.summary: Maximum number of pooled connections to a server bucket (defaults to 5).

member.name: P:Neon.Data.CouchbaseSettings.MinPoolConnections
member.summary: Minimum number of pooled connections to a server bucket (defaults to 2).

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.CreateUuid
member.summary: Generates a URI-safe globally unique ID.

remarks.note: The value returned is a converted to base-64 and then made URI safe by replacing "=" characters with "-" and "/" to "_" and also removing any "=" padding charcters.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntityRef(System.String)
member.summary: Extracts the entity reference from an entity key.

remarks.para: This implements a common convention where Couchbase entities are persisted using a key formed by appending entity ID to the entity type, separated by a double colon ("::"). This makes entity types available for filtering when managing cross datacenter replication.
This method extracts the string after the first ("::") as the document ID.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntityKey(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Generates an entity key from the entity reference and entity type.
member.exception: Thrown if is null or empty.

remarks.para: Stoke follows a common convention where Couchbase entities are persisted using a key formed by appending entity reference to the entity type, separated by a double colon ("::"). This makes entity types available for filtering when managing cross datacenter replication.
This method concatenates the entity type and ID using a ("::") separator.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntityKey(System.String)
member.summary: Generates an entity key from the a GUID and entity type.

remarks.para: Stoke follows a common convention where Couchbase entities are persisted using a key formed by appending entity ID to the entity type, separated by a double colon ("::"). This makes entity types available for filtering when managing cross datacenter replication.
This method concatenates the entity type and ID using a ("::") separator.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntityPropertyInfo``1
member.summary: Returns the serializable property information for an entity.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntityProperties``1
member.summary: Returns the names of an entity's properties that will be serialized to JSON.

remarks.para: This method is handy when manually building N1QL query strings when you want to return all entity fields but you don't want to use select * because this nests each result into a property named for the bucket. I'm not entirely sure why Couchbase does this.
remarks.note: This method will include all public entity properties that do not have the and this also honors the property names specified by any attributes.

member.name: M:Neon.Data.EntityHelper.GetEntitySelectProperties``1
member.summary: Returns the comma separated names of an entity's properties in a form where they can be easily added to a manually created N1QL statement.
member.returns: The comma separated list of of property names.

remarks.para: This method is handy when manually building N1QL query strings when you want to return all entity fields but you don't want to use select * because this nests each result into a property named for the bucket. You may use the result to replace the star (*) in the select with the explicit property names.
remarks.note: This method will include all public entity properties that do not have the and this also honors the property names specified by any attributes.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.BinderAttachmentAttribute
member.summary: Used to tag the properties of a binder document's interface definition so that the entity-gen tool will be able to generate code that implements the pattern for Couchbase Lite document attachments.

member.name: P:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.BinderAttachmentAttribute.AttachmentName
member.summary: The optional case insensitve name for the Couchbase Lite document attachment to be associated with this property. Otherwise, this will default to the property name.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.BinderDocumentAttribute
member.summary: Used to tag an interface indicating that the entity-gen should generate a Couchbase Lite entity document class that that implements the pattern for the document attachments.

remarks.para: Entity document classes that implement the pattern for the attachments are referred to as binder documents. You'll need to define an interface that includes zero or more properties that will be mapped to document attachments. You must also define a separate interface that defines the document contents.
The binder document interface must be tagged with the , passing the type of the entity interface definition and the binder document properties must be tagged with the .

member.name: M:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicEntity.Create``1(Newtonsoft.Json.Linq.JObject,Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.IDynamicEntityContext)
member.summary: Constructs a from a .

remarks.para: This method is capable of instantiating derived entities in a future-proof manner. This is possible for entities whose defining interfaces were tagged with a value. This is set to a unique identifier for the type within the application domain.

Entities serialize their own type identifier as well as the identifiers for any inherited types to the internal JSON property. The type identifiers are formatted into a list of colon (:) separated values with the current type's identifier listed first, followed by its parent's identifier and so on, all the way to the root entity's identifier.

This identifier list provides the information necessary to dynamically instantiate the derived entity that best fits the data. For example, say you release a product that defines a base IProduct interface with ICandy derived from it. IProduct defines a Name as property and ICandy adds Calories.

An application can persist a base IProduct instance to the database as well as a derived ICandy. Calling this method to load the base IProduct or ICandy document will simply load it. Calling this method to load IProduct but passing the ICandy document, will actually create an ICandy instance but return it cast to the base type (IProduct).
Applications can test entity types using the usual C# is/as operators or switch on the entity's type property, if one was tagged using .

This also enables future-proofing. Say version 1.0 of an application only knew about IProduct and ICandy. Then, version 2.0 is released that adds IBeer which also derives from IProduct and persists some beer to a database. Loading an IBeer document as an IProduct from version 1.0 will still work, even though v1 is not aware of this type. An IProduct entity will be returned (what else can be done), but the IBeer properties will still be loaded into the underlying JObject.

member.summary: Used to tag an interface such that the entity-gen tool will automatically generate equivalent data model classes derived from .

member.summary: Optional name for the generated class; otherwise the name will default to the interface name with the leading "I" character removed (if present).

member.summary: Optionally indicates that the generated class will be declared as internal rather than public, the default.

summary.para: Optional entity type identifier. This can be set to a string or enum value uniquely identifying the entity type within the application domain.
summary.note: This property must be set for derived interface definitions.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicEntityPropertyAttribute
member.summary: Used to customize code generation for a property definition within an interface tagged by by the entity-gen build tool.

remarks.para: This attribute provides the property which allows for the customization of the string used when the property is serialized to JSON. This allows for the decoupling of entity property names from the database.
remarks.note: You need to be sure that all of the property names are unique within a entity interface and any derived interfaces.
remarks.para: The may be assigned true to generate a read-only property that returns the value specified by the value used to tag the interface.
remarks.note: =true must be set for the base interface of a derived interface heirarchy.
defaults to if =true rather than the actual property name to standardize the serialized type property name on a compact string. Applications can override this behavior by explicitly setting .
remarks.para: may be set to true to have the entity perist a string reference to another entity, rather than the entity itself. This is useful for Couchbase Lite scenarios, where you'd like an entity to reference another its document ID, but have that entity be accessable as a parent entity property. This will simplify UX data binding, etc.

member.name: P:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicEntityPropertyAttribute.Name
member.summary: The optional name to use when serializing the property. This defaults to the defined property name.

summary.para: Optionally indicates that the property will be used to serialize the entity type. The tagged property's type must be either a string or enum type.
summary.note: Entity type properties must define a getter but not a setter and may only be specified for root entity interfaces (not derived ones).
You may not combine this with or =true.
summary.para: The entity-gen code generator will generate this as a read-only property that returns the value specified by the value used to tag the interface.

member.name: P:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicEntityPropertyAttribute.IsLink
member.summary: Optionally indicates that the property is a reference to another entity rather than holding the entity itself.

remarks.para: Reference properties will persist a string value that identifies the specific entity being referenced (e.g. a Couchbase Lite document ID or perhaps a file system path). Advanced implementations can implement to provide a way for entities to resolve the string reference into the referenced entity instance.
remarks.note: You may not combine this with =true.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicIncludeAttribute
member.summary: Used to tag a class or enum such that the entity-gen Visual Studio build tool will automatically include the type in the generated output. This is somewhat limited, as described in the remarks.

remarks.para: Data models often need to reference enum types and sometimes its useful for a model library to be able to include constant definitions. You can tag a class with this attribute to include the class in the generated model output.
remarks.note: Only the class public constant definitions will be include in the generated output.

member.name: P:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicIncludeAttribute.Namespace
member.summary: Optional namespace for the generated class; otherwise the namespace will default to the namespace of the tagged class.

member.name: P:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.DynamicIncludeAttribute.IsInternal
member.summary: Optionally indicates that the generated class will be declared as internal rather than public, the default.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.IDynamicEntityContext
member.summary: Implements methods used to resolve entity links.

remarks.para: Advanced entity persistence frameworks, like the Neon Couchbase Lite extensions, implement this interface to provide allowing entities to link to one another. Links are specified as opaque strings. For Couchbase Lite, these will be document IDs. Other frameworks can specify something else.
attempts to load an entity, given its link. The method returns null if the linked entity doesn't exist and will throw an exception if there was some other kind of error.
attempts to load a document, given its link. The method returns null if the linked document doesn't exist and will throw an exception if there was some other kind of error.

member.name: M:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.IDynamicEntityContext.LoadEntity``1(System.String,System.Func{System.Boolean}@)
member.summary: Instantiates the entity of the requested type by dereferencing the string passed.
member.param: Optionally returns as a function that will determine whether the linked entity has been deleted from its context. This may also return as null.
member.returns: The loaded entity or null if it doesn't exist.
member.exception: The implementation should throw an exception if the entity couldn't be loaded due to some kind of error, but not if the entity simply doesn't exist.

remarks.para: Advanced entity contexts such as that implemented by the Neon Couchbase Lite extension will return a non-null value that can be tested to check if the entity still exists.

member.name: M:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.IDynamicEntityContext.LoadDocument``1(System.String,System.Func{System.Boolean}@)
member.summary: Instantiates the document of the requested type by dereferencing the string passed.
member.param: Optionally returns as a function that will determine whether the linked document has been deleted from its context. This may also return as null.
member.returns: The loaded document or null if it doesn't exist.
member.exception: The implementation should throw an exception if the document couldn't be loaded due to some kind of error, but not if the entity simply doesn't exist.

remarks.para: Advanced entity contexts such as that implemented by the Neon Couchbase Lite extension will return a non-null value that can be tested to check if the document still exists.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.Internal.DocLinkMapper`1
member.summary: Platform use only: Used by implementations to map a property to a linked instance.

remarks.note: This class is intended for use only by classes generated by the entity-gen build tool.
remarks.para: This class is used to link a value to an external entity document. The property value will act as the document link and the passed to the constructor (if any) will be used to dereference the link and load the document.

Linked documents are loaded on demand and cached when the getter is called. Subsequent calls to the getter will return the cached value. The getter will return null if the link is null or if the referenced document doesn't exist.
remarks.note: This class will simply return null if no is present.

member.name: T:Neon.Couchbase.DynamicData.Internal.LinkMapper`1
member.summary: Platform use only: Used by implementations to map a property to a linked instance.

remarks.note: This class is intended for use only by classes generated by the entity-gen build tool.
remarks.para: This class is used to link a value to an external entity. The property value will act as the entity link and the passed to the constructor (if any) will be used to dereference the link and load the entity.

Linked entities are loaded on demand and cached when the getter is called. Subsequent calls to the getter will return the cached value. The getter will return null if the link is null or if the referenced entity doesn't exist.
remarks.note: This class will simply return null if no is present.
